Fields.DialogueText: Hey! Up there!
What?
I can hear footsteps, so I know you're up there! Grab that wrench, the one on the table, and pass it down to me.
Pass you a wrench?

Fields.MenuText: Sure. The wrench on the table... Here you go.
Get it yourself.
Take a break from your repairs and come up here.

Fields.DialogueText: Took you long enough, but thanks.
What?
I don't know who you think you are, refusing orders from your Belle, but I'm going to find out!
Oh! It's you, Kapitan.
Don't pretend you didn't recognize my voice.
Eh. It's tough to hear clearly while working down there.
Fair enough.
So... apparently you believe there's something that warrants my attention more than repairs to our propulsion.
We're going to pass near Sevastopol, and I thought you might want to take a look.
You overestimate how sentimental I can be... but I am glad you told me. I'll come up soon.
*ALARM*
How about right now?
Hm. I guess some sentimental Morganas also want to visit Sevastopol. Let's go!
@BATTLE
You heard me.
Have the Morganas been shooting blanks recently? Maybe they've been running low on ammunition.
You've got to be kidding me.
Look at my armor! It's like they've hardly been trying!

Fields.MenuText: Do you always have to act so tough?
Well, we certainly can't thank your nimble evasion capabilities for our survival...
You really can take a beating.

Fields.DialogueText: If I flinch, so will the troops. As the ship's First Comrade, I must set the example for strong combat discipline.
Tsk tsk. Perhaps, Kapitan, you should have helped with the engine repairs, da?
My iron will is my true armor, Kapitan.
I rather enjoy besting the Neizvestniy flot. Defeating Morganas is even more fun when I imagine they are crewed by reactionaries.
Just remember that, when it comes to Morganas, we all play for the same team.
Teamwork, da, da. That I also respect.
Let's keep doing our part, shall we? I need us ready to bring aboard marines for a troop transport mission. They've been tasked with destroying a dam built by Morganas.
I am fully ready, Kapitan.
Are you sure?
Perhaps you are used to working with young, inexperienced Belles... but maybe you will learn in time. When I say I am ready, I am ready.
Thanks for clarifying, Profintern. When I told you I wanted your input this is almost exactly what I meant. Almost exactly!
Don't mention it.
@BATTLE
The marines are aboard, Kapitan.
Fast and efficient. Nice work, Profintern.
Of course.
How did you load all of the extra food so quickly?
Loading extra food was unnecessary. Our galley will support the soldiers' needs.
How are we going to feed all of them?
We won't have to feed them for very long. You will see.

Fields.MenuText: So... after we drop them off for the mission, somebody else takes care of them.
We have to take care of those troops. We should get more provisions.
What do you mean, "for very long?"

Fields.DialogueText: Er, no... Not exactly.
Didn't you hear what I said? It is not going to be a problem.
Is this your first war? I thought it was obvious.
Once the mission begins, most of the marines will die.
We will only have a few wounded and survivors to feed after the battle begins.
Profintern...
Don't hold me responsible. Blame the Morganas. They are the ones who will kill those troops. You've seen the same reports I have.
That's probably fair. Now let's get that food loaded.
@BATTLE
Ah. There may be a problem with that. Look to the south.
They will be storming Morgana fortifications on a dead island, Kapitan. An SVT-38 is only so useful when you have nothing human to shoot.
... I know.
Any thoughts on how we can improve their odds would be gratefully accepted.
Kapitan, we will get them where they need to be. We will protect them from other ships, and perhaps we can bombard the infestation from the sea.
And that is all we can do. I think you want to believe that if you try hard enough you can win this war alone - and that way lies madness.
In fairness, I know I'm not alone.
Da. But I do not back down from allegations of madness.
This is something I never expected to see...
I thought it might be a good idea to help make food for the troops today.
Curious. Are you adopting the ways of the proletariat now?
Maybe I'm just trying to take care of those in my charge.
And thus you truly understand your place. Leader and servant.

Fields.MenuText: Quit romanticizing it. I'm just pitching in to let the crew and troops know that I care.
Feel free to help out.
Where should I get my hammer and sickle tattoo? On my arm, or maybe a big one on my back?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be coy, Kapitan. I'm glad your heart understands, even if your head does not want to admit it.
I have been. I am quite popular with the mechanics for helping out in the engine room.
Hmph. I don't enjoy being mocked, Kapitan.
Let's just try to keep morale up, for their sake.
Da. Of course.
@BATTLE
On that note, how're you doing with Sullivan? And Tate? Is everyone behaving themselves?
Tate is a grandstanding fool.
Really?
... Nyet. He's just not as clever as he thinks he is. But at least now he's competing with me instead of just ignoring me.
Still doesn't sound ideal.
"Ideal" is for children and philosophers, Kapitan. We can work together. It's enough.
Fair enough.
... What're you doing?
I'm stepping in to assist, obviously. I need to be sure you don't accidentally poison my crew.
Uh-huh. Just watch and learn how a master of the culinary arts works.
I'm not sure those words mean what you think they mean.
How utterly disappointing, Kapitan.
Always a promising start to a conversation.
Here I am, stopping by your cabin, and I see that you are taking your meals in here.
I had so much hope after seeing you help out in the galley, but you still sequester yourself and eat in here.
Why do you isolate yourself this way? Do you truly believe you are superior to the others?

Fields.MenuText: Somebody has to be the captain, in case you forgot.
I think you're missing the point.
Of course I don't. Is it really such a crime just to want to be alone for half an hour?

Fields.DialogueText: *sigh*
Then educate me, wise leader.
A crime? Nyet. But I don't see the value in it.
All things in moderation, then.
Even if they all smile and say they enjoy my company, some would just be doing their best to be polite and respectful.
I'm sure there are a number of crew members who would prefer that I leave them alone when they are relaxing. Eating my meals alone lets them avoid me.
I understand your decision, although I don't like it. Hierarchies cause more problems than they solve.
Noted. Back to why you visited in the first place, though - did you have something you needed to discuss?
Da. We are not far from the drop off area. If you want to talk to any of those marines before they...
Depart?
Right. Depart. You have a few more hours.
Thanks.
Mighty Kapitan, now would you like me to scrub your dirty dishes?
@BATTLE
You did ask for candor.
True. What have I done now?

Fields.MenuText: A common naval tradition.
I'm eating while I work. You'll note the papers strewn around.

Fields.DialogueText: A captain often eats separately from the crew, and even from the other officers.

Fields.MenuText: ... Really?
I have to maintain some distance from the crew and troops. Being too familiar undermines my ability to lead.
Sometimes I need privacy in order to function.

Fields.DialogueText: You know the hours I work. I'm working now. And there are things I just can't do in the middle of a crowd.
I don't think it's unreasonable to grab the occasional moment when I wouldn't be missed and just... get things done.
I understand. But it's a missed opportunity - the crew values seeing you share in their free time as well as in their labors. It keeps you from seeming elitist.
Clutter hardly makes the impression better, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: I'm trying to think of last-minute preparations for those marines. Anything we might have missed.

Fields.DialogueText: There's nothing.
There's always something.
Improving morale by moving confidently among the crew, perhaps?
Heh. Okay, okay. Point taken.
Back to why you visited in the first place, though - did you have something you needed to discuss?
I think you must already know. We are not far from the drop off area. If you want to talk to any of those marines before they...
Do you want an honest answer?
Nyet.
Our guns are ready to soften up the defenses, Kapitan. I will do you the courtesy of waiting for your order to commence.
Kapitan, I do understand. You know I do.
I respect your concern for our brave fighters, but once they leave our ship, they have their own job to do. This isn't really about us anymore.
You're right, but... damn.
*ALARM*
And these witches of the Neizvestniy flot are willing to oblige! How gratifying!
Who are we to deny them?
I'm glad we can agree on that...
@BATTLE
The order's given. Blow as many holes in that thing as you can - I want those marines to be able to stroll right up to the front door.
You can want all you like.

Fields.MenuText: Tell me about it.
Point taken.
Let's not bicker in front of the bridge crew.

Fields.DialogueText: I can, of course. Extensively.
That's... novel.
Hmph.
Just keep raining hell on that station, or whatever it is, for as long as you can. Anything we destroy now won't be shelling our troops on the beach.
*ALARM*
We're almost in position, Kapitan. There's just a bit of a barricade to run.
I can't say I'm surprised.
@BATTLE
The beach is in range, Kapitan. Let's keep shelling the defenses.
Fire at will. Give the marines a fighting chance.
Da. With pleasure.
*BOOM*
And they're off.
We're sitting ducks until the troops have all deployed, so keep a sharp eye on the horizon for enemy reinforcements.
*BOOM*
We've been harassed by Morganas continuously on this mission. It's only a matter of time before more of them show up.
*BOOM*
I hate to be a pessimist, but you're right. When they show up...

Fields.MenuText: ... keep all guns focused on the shore bombardment. I want our troops to have cover.
... switch all guns to deal with incoming Morganas. If they take us out, the troops don't have a chance.
... be ready to run.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you sure that's a good idea? We can't help them if the Morganas sink us first.
I agree. Troops paddling ashore would have no defense against the Neizvestniy flot hags.
That is the last thing I would ever choose!
Just keep watching the horizon. I won't relax until all of the troops are away.
*GUNFIRE*
They will proceed as quickly as they can, Kapitan. They know the dangers, too.
The last of the marines have made landfall, Kapitan.
It's up to them now.
*GUNFIRE*
Cease fire, Profintern.
You don't need to tell me that! I'm not one to waste ammunition.

Fields.MenuText: Right. Sorry - sleep deprivation may be catching up with me.
Take a breath. I wasn't trying to upset you.
You really hate taking orders, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: You shouldn't let that happen.
What difference does that make?
Perhaps I do!
... Are you just going to stand there looking glum?
I'm not feeling glum, for what it's worth. I don't see any dead bodies on that beach.
No. But their real assault hasn't yet begun. And the extraction will be fierce as well.
Noted. But we're doing okay so far.
Hmph.
... Kapitan.
I have not painted in a few days, and that needs to change. When this business is over, I will be taking to my canvasses. You might tell the crew it wouldn't be wise to disturb me without cause.
I'll take that under advisement. Thanks for the, uh, warning.
Now let's move the ship away from the beach in case we have to deal with visitors.
@BATTLE
Yes?
Profintern! Climb down! You've been up there for hours!
I can't hear you! Climb up if you want to talk to me!
But you're sitting atop the highest mast!
What? Say that again, I can't hear you!
Come down so we don't have to keep shouting!
Climb up! I can't hear you from all the way up here!
I said climb down!
I can't hear you! Did you say you were too cowardly to climb up?

Fields.MenuText: Climb down!
Fine! I'll climb up!
Okay. More deep-fried kotlyeti for the Kapitan.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't hear you! Let me climb down first!
I can't hear you! Stay right there while I climb down!
I HEARD THAT!
What do you want, Kapitan?
Nothing in particular. I just enjoy talking to you, despite the occasional abuse.
I needed some... perspective.
In the painterly sense? Lines converging on a point on the horizon? Or more philosophical?
I was going to ask if you were going to respond to every question with another question, but I guess the point is moot.
Da. And why would you ask me that, anyway?
@BATTLE
I'm climbing down!
*ALARM*
Hello there.
Do we really have real food? Not just the crates of half-spoiled American MREs someone traded for surplus socks?
No. I made that up.
... I am now your sworn enemy.
No, you're not.
No? Well... I suppose you may have redeeming qualities I'll remember in time. I'll reserve judgment.
The phrase you're looking for is "constructive criticism."
Uh-huh.
And, honestly, I was getting a little bit worried about you. You've been up there a while.
... People don't generally ask me questions like that.
Do you mind?
Why would I mind?
But if you're here to talk about the situation with the marines, you don't need to make small talk.
Is it really that hard to believe I'm genuinely interested?
Is that a trick question?
Take that! And THAT!
Profintern? Are you down here in the ammunition storage?
Why, yes! It's a wonderful location because it's so private. I could work here without being interrupted by, say, my kapitan...
Sorry. I'll leave you to it.
... That's not necessary. I assume you're looking for me for a reason, da?
Excellent.

Fields.MenuText: Good for you!
Can I see it?
We miss you up on deck, but at least it's for a good cause.

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo, Kapitan.
It is not finished. Peeking would be unwise.
... I can't tell if you're being sarcastic.
I promise you will see it when the piece is finished.
Thank you.
I'm looking forward to it. Those sketches you've left lying around have been exceptionally good.
Oh...
Well...
Now you look like somebody walked over your grave. Are you all right?
Da... yes, fine. I just need my privacy again for a little while, Kapitan.
... After the battle. I promise.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Not an important one. I just thought I'd treat you to a chocolate bar while we're both technically off-duty.
If you're painting, I really don't want to interrupt.
Well, it's done, and there's no point crying about it. You said you bring chocolate?
I did and I do. Here you go.
Should I ask how the painting's going?
Why wouldn't you?
I don't know. If it were going badly, it might be frustrating to talk about.
Fear not - I would shout about it instead! Much better.
Mm. Mmmm. Don't tell anyone I said so - but the capitalists do a good job with their chocolate.
My lips are sealed.
So. The painting is going well. Not flawless, but it's taking shape.
Profintern, I came out of my way to come down here and talk to you. Ergo, I like talking to you. Ergo, you're missed when you're not on deck.
But I really want to see what you're working on.
Oh. Well. Spasibo, Kapitan.
Look at that! Quite a bold painting, don't you think?
Maybe a little too bold.
Huh? What do you mean?
Look, near the bottom. I don't know what will happen when the Captain sees that.
Huh?
The face. Doesn't it look a lot like...
Whoa! I see it now. Looks like Profintern couldn't help herself.
Esposito. Sullivan. Is that Profintern's new painting?
Um... whoa, is that the time?
Bye!
Why were they so spooked?
Stark red and black patterns, geometric designs...
A heroic female standing proudly and holding a huge hammer...
That she just used to knock out her unconscious enemy...
And her enemy looks an awful lot like...
My dear kapitan!
Like my new painting?

Fields.MenuText: It's certainly something. But we should probably hide it before the political officer comes around.
It's definitely the most vivid political cartoon I've ever seen.
That's a disturbingly good likeness of my battered, unconscious body. I'm actually kind of impressed.

Fields.DialogueText: What? You can't suppress free expression forever, Kapitan! I will take this down, but under protest.
My art?! A cartoon? I... I... I knew you couldn't appreciate it! I'm taking it down!
I doubt somebody like you could ever appreciate true art. I'm taking this down!
Listen, we'll talk about it later. We both have places we need to be now.
Hmph!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All engines ahead at flank speed! Get us to the rendezvous point as fast as possible!
It take it we've had our orders.
Da. I sent someone to find you, but I didn't think you'd object if I got us moving.
It is time to recover the marines.

Fields.MenuText: Good.
Glad to hear it. Though captains do typically enjoy knowing what their ship is doing.
Good. But I should be the one giving that order.

Fields.DialogueText: Good!
Don't expect me to typically enjoy explaining everything to you.
Da, da, da. Forgive me just this once - there was no time to waste.
Anything else from Command that I should know before I read the report for myself?
Da. Casualties for the troops are as expected. Severe.
@BATTLE
... Tell me we're making good speed.
Da. Comrade Tate tells me the tingling feeling in my engines means they're at peak efficiency.
The troops from the mission took heavy losses. We have to get the wounded survivors aboard quickly if we're going to save any of them.
I assure you, Kapitan, I am doing everything in my power to get them aboard.
Let's try to coordinate this better. The fishing boats in the area are causing a traffic jam.
Get out of my way! Soviet cruiser coming through!
This recovery effort is not working...
Move your little boats out of my way or I will ram you out of the way!

Fields.MenuText: I'm trusting you to sort this out, Profintern.
We should probably find you a megaphone.
Ramming boats is while on a rescue mission is... the opposite of rescue!

Fields.DialogueText: Let me handle it, and I will.
These people should probably use their eyes and see the light cruiser bearing down on them!
They'll learn to get out of my way soon enough.
I can take it from here. Perhaps you can talk to Command and inform them of our progress.
Sounds like a plan. If you feel like shouting more at the fishing boats, you formally have my blessing - they shouldn't be this far out with active Morganas in the region.
Our doctors have their hands full, and we're not going to make their jobs any easier if elbows are flying. We need to save as many wounded as we possibly can.
Of course. But we have to be fast, or else the Neizvestniy flot will pounce on us here. As you suggest, Morganas will be drawn to this carnage like sharks.
@BATTLE
So that on the horizon, is that just fins?
Da, da, da. It's better if they starve. I understand.
Now you're just arguing for the sake of arguing.
... I find it relieves stress.
Sorry. Right now I think we need that stress.
*KNOCK*
Come in.
So! You have invited me once again to the private residence of the hierarchy itself.
My cabin? Yes.
Da, the luxurious chamber of power...
Really? Luxurious?
Fine. Perhaps not exactly luxurious.
Which... is intentional, of course, because I will not be First Comrade on a ship that would indulge itself in such capitalist gestures.

Fields.MenuText: You'd change your mind if you knew how good I looked on a golden throne.
So you're shabby... on purpose.
I... have no response.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph.
Stop putting words in my mouth.
Hardly surprising, Kapitan.
And so you summon me because... your typewriter needs repairs again?
No. I wanted to talk about the wounded that we evacuated from the beach.
Our ship's doctors stabilized a good number of them.
How many made it?
Eight.
Just eight?
There weren't many survivors to begin with, and hauling them aboard quickly tended to open or aggravate their wounds.
I know you hoped for better, but the fact that we were able to save any at all is something of an accomplishment.
That's--
*ALARM*
Damn! It will have to wait. Set general quarters and get our guns up immediately.
Hurry up, you say. Wait, you say. *sigh*
@BATTLE
Make your report, Lieutenant Esposito.
Spotted some fast-moving shapes on the radar, Captain. I thought it might be a possible Morgana movement in the distance.
Neizvestniy flot scum!
All engines ahead flank and get the crew to battle stations. Our work is cut out for us.
Um...
You heard me, Esposito. Just because our kapitan is standing here doesn't mean you can't take action. Get going!

Fields.MenuText: Profintern.
Go ahead, Lieutenant. The insubordination is a topic for another time.
You heard the Belle.

Fields.DialogueText: I regret nothing.
That's what I thought.
Hmph.
Visual confirmation. Multiple Morganas heading east across the Black Sea.
Very well, Esposito. Move in to intercept and engage the targets.
Aye-aye, Captain.
Right. When I say it everybody glares. When the Kapitan says it it's just "aye-aye."
That's what being the captain means, ma'am.
... Da. I'll be in the engine room cleaning oil filters. If anybody needs me, that's where I'll be.
It's fine, Lieutenant. Just devote your attention to helping us win this thing.
Of course, Captain.
@BATTLE
... Sorry, Captain. Could've handled that better.
She evades all defenders as she drives with purpose to her objective...
Profintern? You have a minute?
She dodges to the left and prepares to fire...
Profintern? Can you stop with the soccer ball for a second?
She shoots...
*SMACK*
Oh, for the love of...!
GOAL!

Fields.MenuText: ... You just hit me in the face with a soccer ball.
Assaulting your superior officer is a crime, you know.
"Goal?" Really?!

Fields.DialogueText: It was an accident.
It was just a ball. You should be...
Just a bit of exercise.
Oh. Here. I'm... sorry about that.
Fine. Okay. But right now I need your help.
Of course. Anything!
Command is asking questions about the casualty rate on that assault. Nobody on their side saw how bad it was going to be, and they're trying to figure out what went wrong.
I don't like the sound of that.
*ALARM*
Or that!
@BATTLE
Hang on. Do you have a handkerchief or something? I've got a nosebleed here.
Listen, you don't have to like me, but--
I do like you! Who said I didn't like you?
... You spent dozens of hours on a painting of yourself having beaten me senseless with a giant hammer.
That sounds worse than it really is.
So I want an expanded report - the most thorough write-up we can manage. We want them fixing problems, not just spreading blame around.
Let me see if I understand this correctly.
All right.
Command says that even though the assault on the Morgana... "enigma structure" was technically a success, losses were too high.
That's what I understood from their message to all of the participating units.
Including us.
That's right.
And because so many marines were lost in the attack, they do not have enough people to commence additional missions.

Fields.MenuText: Don't take it personally. We did our part as well as anyone possibly could.
The loss of life was atrocious. Command's right to hold an inquiry.
Maybe we could have coordinated the attack better. If we'd worked faster, fewer men would have--

Fields.DialogueText: I agree with you.
But who is to blame for the failure?
We're not responsible!
Everybody did their part, including us.
But even that isn't always good enough.
If I were in charge, we would have had far fewer losses.
If you're arguing that the world would be a better place if there were infantry Belles, I'm not going to disagree. I'd never go on dry land without you if I had a choice.
Well, you're smarter than the men in charge.
Big generals and admirals make their ridiculous plans and blame the lowly soldiers when it doesn't work.
I'm so tired of it! I'm tired of those pompous fools who don't remember or care what it's like to actually fight!
Hey, Profintern...
WHAT?
I'm on your side, you know. In fact, you might say we're in the same...
Oh, please. Don't say it...
Boat.
That's so... haha! That's so stupid, Kapitan.
Get some rest. I'll work on our report to Command, all right?
Thanks. I... I think I'll do that. Excuse me.
*ALARM*
Battle stations, everyone!
@BATTLE
*sigh*
Hey, do you have a minute?
I'm working on a painting.
Am I going to be in this painting?
Ha! I don't think so. Not this time.
It's just a geometric pattern.
I like the stripes that run across the middle. Very... avant-garde.
Well, that's the idea.
You said some interesting things about the people at Command. About generals and admirals...
How did that report turn out, by the way?
Fine, thanks. I just sent them the details about where and when we provided gunfire support, where and when we deployed the marines.
Just like that?
But that was basically it. So - what's on your mind?
Some of the crew thinks I bark about political theory and revolution because I just like to stir up trouble all day long, but it's not true.
Those ideas are actually important to me. I believe in them. They could make the world better if people would listen.

Fields.MenuText: I hope they don't. Communism is a terrible idea.
Making people listen is one of the hardest things in the world. Making them understand is even harder.
People are entitled to their opinions.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, make sure you understand it before you condemn it.
You make it look easy sometimes, Kapitan.
These aren't opinions. They're facts.
I think you, like everybody else, just want to be heard and understood.
There's a lot more to it than just that, but I admit that part is true.
Anyway, I'm not particularly observant, if you hadn't noticed. For the time being, I think having a patient kapitan to talk to will see me through.
A patient kapitan and big guns.
@BATTLE
That's fair.
Don't make me blush, First Comrade!
In that case, I'll let you be.
... But I wouldn't mind company.
*ALARM*
Kapitan... one more thing.
Yes?
The last painting.
My original idea was that you'd been hurt and I was defending you. The First Comrade standing up for Kapitan and crew, you see?
Changing the subject - did I mention we might finally have a rabbi on board in a couple of weeks? I hear there's a Frenchman looking for a posting as a chaplain.
That could cause more trouble than it's worth, Kapitan.
Moscow signed off on chaplains on Neutrality Fleet assignments, however grudgingly. If you want spiritual guidance, you're entitled.
And you've received one too many head wounds if you think they'd smile at someone like me taking advantage.
Depressingly fair point.
But I couldn't find a way to make it look right, and I got frustrated, and... it was just easier to paint something provocative in the end.
Which was lazy. I see that now.
But I need you to know that it was never, ever meant to suggest that, you know, I... can't tolerate your presence. In moderation.

Fields.MenuText: The feeling is mutual.
Oh... kay.
I like you too.

Fields.DialogueText: Good, then. Good.
Da. That went without saying.
I also offered some suggestions about air support, for whatever they're worth.
Duck!
Nice kick.
My reflexes are improving.
I think it's possible that advance warning may have played a part as well.

Fields.MenuText: Probably didn't hurt.
I like how you had time to warn me, but not enough time to stop yourself from kicking a ball at my face.
Nope. I'm just on fire today.

Fields.DialogueText: Compared to a football in the face? Nyet.
Take what you can get, Kapitan.
I can kick more things at you if you care to test that proposition.
Maybe another time.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad to see you blowing off some steam.
I'm happy to see you playing a game with the crew.

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo. It's easy to forget how good exercise can feel when you work long hours for weeks at a time - not that I'm complaining.
We have a lot to worry about. This is a healthy distraction for all of us.
Well, I don't want to interrupt you more than I already have - I really just wanted to compliment you on your painting. The crew really seems to enjoy it.
Ah. Well, I was inspired by my favorite Constructivist artists.
A big mechanical star blasting colors and light across an ocean? It’s... amazing.
Kapitan, please....
Please what?
... Are you blushing?
Don't be-
I just-
Never mind!
What was that all about?
*ALARM*
Damn.
@BATTLE
... Did *you* enjoy it?
Nice dodge.
Roger, Command. We are rendezvousing with the Black Sea Fleet units now. Profintern, out.
Another two Soviet ships spotted off the port beam, Kapitan! They’re taking station alongside us.
So we have a small flotilla now. They all look... experienced.
What exactly are you trying to imply about the other ships in our task force?
Um...

Fields.MenuText: They're old.
They... aren't rookies.
Nothing. The rust on their hulls makes them look... distinguished.

Fields.DialogueText: Is that all you see?
The way you say it, it doesn't sound like a compliment.
They have guns and they still float. We must make do with that.
You realize my keel was laid in 1913, right? I am about the same age as these veterans.
You make that easy to forget.
Are you saying that I look young, or that I act immaturely?
... How much trouble will I be in if I say "both?"
Ha! I think you are the one blushing now.
Do you think I can? Perhaps I am too old for you. Perhaps my engines will not be able to keep up with the rest of the task force.
Well, this seems like a good time to change the subject. We need to get this task force moving.
All right, all right.
@BATTLE
Reports are coming in from Kerch, Captain. It's... nuts.
Evocative phrase, Lieutenant, but light on detail.
Right. The Soviets drove off some kind of Morgana push, but the enemy subs seem to have deployed some kind of... underwater earth-moving equipment.
Visibility's a mess, and the people on the Peninsula are under toxic clouds - but there are tentative reports that the Kerch Strait has been expanded. Even deepened.
That's not something you can do in a couple of days, Lieutenant. Not meaningfully.
It's not something *we* can do. But from all accounts the peninsula is being chewed to bits.
Profintern! What are you doing back here?
Signaling to one of the Soviet ships. She’s taking heavy fire and wants to withdraw. I am telling her to keep fighting.
We've already lost three destroyers. We're not going to last long like this.
If the shells are falling on us, then they're not falling on Kerch. For keeping the enemy out of the Sea of Azov, it's a fair trade.

Fields.MenuText: Don't give us credit for doing it until it's done.
That doesn't mean those destroyers don't need relief.
Actually, that was your cue to say that I was being defeatist and victory is right around the corner.

Fields.DialogueText: It will be! I assure you, Kapitan.
Then let's give it to them!
I thought that was obvious.
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
Dammit, if that destroyer doesn't get those fires on her deck under control....
She's not a woken Belle, Kapitan. It may be beyond her.
*BOOM*
Captain... we've got reports of Morgana sightings in the Bay of Arabat. They got past us in the fighting. I don't know how.
Dammit!
Curse later! There's another wave incoming!
Captain... we've received orders to withdraw. Awaiting confirmation, but--
Nyet!
... Our support from the Black Sea Fleet is literally in flames, and the Morganas are in the Sea of Azov. This mission has failed.
Kapitan!
Confirmed, Captain. We're to fall back toward Sevastopol.
But Kerch! The people!
If we withdraw, the Morganas won't have any particular reason to sit around the Kerch Strait shooting wildly.
*BOOM*
We have our orders! Go!
Profintern? What're you doing in here?
Oh! Prostite menya, Kapitan. I was just... checking on your cabin.
It looks more like you've been hiding in here.
Kapitan...

Fields.MenuText: I'm not complaining. Beats having to climb thirty feet to shout at you.
You should really ask permission first.
I understand.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't joke. I don't want to smile now.
It was the only place I could go to avoid the eyes of the crew.
You do?
Fair enough.
You want to talk about it?
I think so.
... Everything I stand for. Everything I fight for. And yet, we retreated.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah.
There was no strategic value in doing anything else.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't pretend that makes you feel better! I know you too well for that!
Nobody's ordering us to like it.
Our support was gone, our mission had failed, and if we'd stayed and fought against a wall of battleships we'd both be dead now.
Where did those things even come from?!
Best guess is that they're a group that pushed into the Mediterranean from the Atlantic a month or so ago. It was thought they'd split up along the North African coast, but....
The French should've gotten them long before they came to us.
It's not like anyone isn't fighting right now. The French very much included.
... What's the word from the Sea of Azov?
The Morganas have come to Mariupol. But it's no worse than most other port cities have suffered, and they've had time to prepare.
That doesn't make me feel better.

Fields.MenuText: I know.
That doesn't mean it doesn't matter.
I'm sorry.

Fields.DialogueText: Profintern...
*ALARM*
Think blowing the hell out of some Morganas might help?
Da. Very much so.
@BATTLE
I promise, this fight isn't over. Nothing is over.
I... Kapitan....
*ALARM*
Captain? I see an aircraft carrier!
Think how good you'll feel after we sink it.
@BATTLE
The Morganas unleashed hell, but somehow we're still afloat.
That makes us lucky. I don't know how the Soviets' Black Sea Fleet is going to come back from the last few days.
Ask Napoleon what comes from counting the Russians out too soon.
Point taken, Captain.
Have you seen Profintern since the shooting stopped?
I passed by her when she was checking on the gun crews.
How did she look?
In my honest opinion? Shaken up. Maybe it was the combat damage. I heard that can be painful for Belles.

Fields.MenuText: It's never good when she's quiet.
I need her ready to fight again.
She'll be ready when we need her. Count on it.

Fields.DialogueText: Well....
The whole crew needs that.
I hope so, Captain.
This may sound strange, but I like it better when she’s shouting and lecturing about political theory.
I HEARD that, Esposito!
Be careful what you wish for, Lieutenant.
I should go... check on the rest of the ship.
Excellent idea.
How're you holding up?
Invigorated.
Being ordered to retreat - on top of everything else, it was humiliating. It felt like our superiors had lost faith in my ability to do my job.
... It even felt like you had lost faith in me.
Really? Because I never once-
Da, da - I know. But it took a hard fight to make me really believe it. You see?

Fields.MenuText: Sure.
Not really, but if you're happy I'm happy.

Fields.DialogueText: I knew you would.
Ah. This is why we work so well together.
I was right to choose you as my kapitan. It's remotely possible I don't say that enough.
I agree. With both parts.
Heh.
And, for what it's worth, I'm very glad you chose me too.
Heh.
... We should get back to work. But maybe later on you can kick a football at my face or something.
I can hardly wait!
Status report, First Comrade.
Say what you want about old ships, but my hull is still in one piece. Mostly.
I’ll take what I can get. Command needs us back in action at once.
In the Sea of Azov?
Just on the other side of the Strait of Kerch. Mariupol's defenses held, more or less, and what's left of that battleship group has pulled back.
... So my sisters didn't sacrifice themselves in vain.

Fields.MenuText: No.
Not if we finish these things off here.
Nobody every thought they had.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you ready to go?
Could you imagine for even a moment that I wouldn't be?
That's my girl.
@BATTLE
Another summons to the cabin of the nautical aristocrat! Da! Oh great monarch of the seas, your lowly serf reports as ordered.
Da, da. I couldn't help myself that time. It's just our little joke, that's all.
Are you ready? They're waiting for us in the galley.
I'm sure the crew will be glad to see their kapitan helping out in the galley again. It's been some time since you last cooked for them.
I want to show my appreciation. They've been downright heroic.
Such magnanimous praise! But before we go, I wanted to tell you... I mean, give you... something.
A lecture on labor unions?
Pozhaluysta, Kapitan, can we stop the jokes for a moment? This is... Well, just open it.
What's this? A new painting?
Just a small one. A personal one, to express how I feel. Two people standing together.
I hope I captured our likenesses.
You did. Are they... holding hands?
Are they? Hm, I suppose they are.
The painting with the hammer - it was originally going in this direction as well. Then I thought it wouldn't be appreciated and... overcorrected.

Fields.MenuText: Cut it out.
Where's my curtsy, dammit?
Good to see you too.

Fields.DialogueText: You'll have to ask more nicely than that!
Ah, it's good to see you smile every so often!
They look happy, these two.
Da?
Well, it appears you like your gift well enough. So... are you ready to head to the galley? Come on. The crew is probably getting hungry.
Profintern.
Da?
This couple definitely looks happy. And this lady here... I don't think I've ever seen anyone more beautiful.
... Kapitan...
Yes?
... I'm glad you're learning how to appreciate art.
HA!
Listen, if you're interested, I think after we visit the galley you and I should have a long--
*ALARM*
Eta tak razdrazhayet!!
... I couldn't agree more.
Let's just go kill them all and then you can go back to flirting with me.
Sounds like a plan.
